paragraphs.text: Who is a German?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: A spectre is haunting Germany and Europe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the spectre is called PEGIDA
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Until recently only a few people had heard of PEGIDA, acronym for "Patriotic Europeans against the Islamisation of the Occident."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It started as a small protest movement in the eastern city of Dresden against the influx of immigrants, foreign workers and asylum seekers and, above all, against the "Islamisation" of Germany
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Adopting the slogan"We are the people" of the weekly anti-communist demonstrations in 1989 which ultimately led to the overthrow of the German Democratic Republic, PEGIDA's appeal seems to have grown week after week
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The hundreds of demonstrators of the first few Monday evening "walks" in Dresden have swollen to tens of thousands
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Besides Dresden, there are now similar weekly rallies in other big German cities
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: With its history of anti-Semitism and fascism many find it shocking that a considerable number of Germans, particularly in the east of the country, are flocking to a xenophobic, racist and Islamophobic movement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The surge of the anti-Islamisation movement has led to polarisation of the public opinion, many counter demonstrations and a fierce public debate, involving politicians, church leaders and academics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Chancellor Angela Merkel strongly criticised PEGIDA and called on Germans not to attend their rallies
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "Do not follow the people who organise these, for their hearts are cold and often full of prejudice, and even hate," Merkel said in her New Year's Eve speech
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Marginalised
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Not everybody agrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Development Minister Gerd Muller of the Bavarian Christian Social Union (CSU), warned not to exclude PEGIDA sympathisers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "The overwhelming majority of those demonstrators are not racists at all
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Many of them are low income Germans
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: and they feel they are being neglected, while refugees are offered help
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The refugees, but also other migrants, are perceived by these people as competitors
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In spite of our flourishing economy there are millions of poor families in Germany
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The poor feel marginalised and not represented."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The CSU, Merkel's CDU's sister party and longtime political ally, has been accused of showing a bit too much understanding for PEGIDA
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact the CSU's positions on immigration, integration and tougher rules for asylum seekers are quite similar to PEGIDA's
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It may well be that the CSU is distancing itself from Merkel because it is worried about right-wing competitors like the anti-establishment and eurosceptic AfD, Alternative fur Deutschland (Germany's Alternative)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The AfD may succeed in winning over many of the PEGIDA-sympathisers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: AfD-chairman Bernd Lucke has gone out of his way to advocate a dialogue with this "new civil movement" and listen carefully to its arguments
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: At the same time Lucke tried carefully not to alienate the more "respectable" right-wing voters and to distance himself from a too xenophobic discourse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Other AfD leaders are less ambiguous and clearly show support of PEGIDA by participating in their marches and inviting PEGIDA organisers to Saxony's regional parliament
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some German observers don't doubt the existence of an alliance between AfD and PEGIDA
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Analyst Volker Wagener sees the AfD as the "parliamentary voice of the street"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He notes that the AfD manages to score with a xenophobic discourse especially in the east of Germany
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the AfD succeeds in translating PEGIDA's objectives politically and electorally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it may take a role not unsimilar to Marine le Pen's National Front in France and especially Geert Wilders' Freedom Party in the Netherlands
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is a striking similarity between the anti- Islamisation positions of Geert Wilders and PEGIDA
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Like Wilders' Freedom Party, PEGIDA does not only condemn jihadists and Islamist terrorists but Islam itself
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Refugees, asylum seekers, migrants and the islamic religion are all lumped together in a vague, scary, threatening mix
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Both the Freedom Party and PEGIDA claim to defend the "conservation of the Judeo-Christian heritage"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Both claim not to be radical
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: PEGIDA and Wilders' party do in fact appeal to right wing radicals and extremists
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Neo- Nazis and violent"hooligans against Salafists" openly support PEGIDA
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Both forces represent a significant portion of the population in Germany and the Netherlands
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there would be parliamentary elections in the Netherlands now,
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Wilders' Freedom Party would be the first or second political force in the country (depending on which poll to believe)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Germany, around 30 percent of the population thinks PEGIDA's concerns are legitimate
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Some German experts say the debate shows the need for a redefinition of"who is a German" and recognition of Germany as an immigration country
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: According to a recent study, most Germans see somebody as "German" when he or she speaks German well and has a German passport
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Some 38 percent of those polled said that women who wore headscarves could not be German
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: To define a new concept of "German-ness" and promote a welcoming culture of tolerance and openness will not be an easy task, and should probably not be left to the politicians
paragraphs.label: assumption
